data.title: Provide an option to show open editor tabs in multi lines.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  1.14  Insider
- OS Version:
  Win 7 64Bit

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Setting:(default setting)
    "workbench.editor.showTabs": true,
2. Open a few files to edit.

At present, the tabs are shown in one line. If there are too many files opened, the line cannot hold all the tabs, then there is a horizontal scrollbar.
However, the horizontal scrollbar is too thin, it's not very easy to click on it to scroll among the tabs.

So, I suggest, provide an option to show the tabs in multi-lines if the single line can not hold all the tabs.

As I know, UltraEditor and NotePad++ both provide an option to show the tabs.

I hope VSCode also has this option, and leave the user to decide how to show the tabs.

Thanks a lot.

data.title: Add real time collaborate function
Add CSP To Root Document
data.body:
Adds a content security policy to the root document. This limits what can be loaded. Important changes:

* Connect-src is limited to `self` or `https:`
* script-src is limited to `self`
* object and child-src are limited to `self`
* Media allows `self` `http` `https` and `data`

This CSP effects all of VSCode. I've done sanity checks to make sure basics scenarios do not produce any warnings but the CSP may still need adjustment

data.title: Open tabs list is not stored if Windows is shut down
data.body:
I haven't tested if this also affects unsaved files (Hot Exit), but at work I encounter this every day and it's quite frustrating.

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 (Creators Update)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code
2. Open several code files
3. Close VS Code
4. Re-open VS Code
5. Observe that the code files from step 2 are still open
6. Open more code files
7. Restart your computer
8. Open VS Code
9. Observe that the code files from step 6 are not open, only the ones from step 2

data.title: Makefile syntax highlighting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Linux

When editing a makefile, sometimes things don't color as prettily as they could.

I've noticed this when using an `ifeq` block, in particular.

![2017-06-13-185037_841x488_scrot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1015732/27108012-37fcb50a-5069-11e7-8be3-99ad671a8d6e.png)

As you can see, the variables that are indented are not colored, and neither is the `else ifeq`.

data.title: Feature request: WSL remote interpreters for extensions developers
data.body:
Hi,
it would be great for extension developers to know where (between Windows and the Windows Subsystem for Linux) to find the needed dependencies.

For example now some extensions may require to run `ruby` or a gem (e.g. `ripper-tags`), git, etc. that you may have installed under WSL, but Visual Studio Code won't see them unless you install them on Windows too.

Allowing the user to select whether by default these dependencies should be ran from Windows or from WSL would allow extension developers to support both scenarios.

In a way, I think you might have a primary target platform (windows, macos, linux) and an optional secondary one.

This is related to:
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22663
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/28315 (but not sure why this one has been closed / points to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13138 as 13138 seems fixed to me)

(please feel free to close if you consider it a duplicate, but I hope it suggests a different approach)

data.title: Stop find operation at last match of the file
data.body:
VS Code version | OS
------------------ | ----
1.14.0  | Win x64 pro (french)

It may be just me who didn't find the function or setting to enable. Please enlighten me.

## Steps to reproduce

1. Open any file
2. Run the **find** command, `CTRL+F`
3. Query a string you know it exists in multiple place in file
4. Use `F3` or _next_ button to move to next match


## Results

When you reach the last occurrence, the **find** command keep searching by jumping to the first occurrence at the top of the file. You're in a search loop.

## Expectations

When last search occurrence is reached, most of text/code editor will prompt the user if he wants to keep searching the file from the first line. This is a feature I need and should be a toggle one.

data.title: Cannot have multiple instances of VS Code when running as admin
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf, 2017-06-08T16:43:13.058Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|gitignore|codezombiech|0.5.0|
|vscode-markdownlint|DavidAnson|0.9.1|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|
|xml|DotJoshJohnson|1.8.0|
|json-tools|eriklynd|1.0.2|
|git-project-manager|felipecaputo|1.3.2|
|mssql|ms-mssql|1.0.0|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.10.0|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|1.3.2|
|team|ms-vsts|1.118.2|
|gitblame|waderyan|1.11.2|
|markdown-pdf|yzane|0.1.7|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open an instance of Visual Studio Code to "Run as administrator"
2. Right-click on the window in the Windows task bar and choose "New Window" OR just try and launch a new instance of VS Code the regular way (click desktop shortcut, launch via start menu, etc.).
3. Nothing happens.

You would expect a new instance/window of Visual Studio Code to appear, but nothing happens. The functionality works as expected when not running VS Code as admin. It seems that when you are running VS Code as admin, you can never have more than one instance running at a time.

data.title: Added darwinHelpBook and darwinHelpName to build process for MacOS
data.body:
Fixes #18697 

Note: The Helpbook files need not exist to fix this bug.  Creating a thorough and useful Helpbook is a large feature in its own right. This commit simply enables that book to be made in the future.

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body:
Please can we have a setting to hide the vertical scroll-bar if the very awesome minimap is visible? With the minimap there, the vertical scroll-bar is just a waste of space.

![capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6370145/27098953-8b684438-5079-11e7-8a59-bc54529b380a.PNG)

It would also be very cool to show the current view-area in the minimap by changing its background colour in that region - like full-fat Visual Studio.

data.title: Add DocumentSymbolProvider support for indicating imports
data.body: Currently imported classes, types, constants and so on look like regular variables. It would be useful to either have a separate `SymbolKind` to indicate imports or a separate boolean flag (so a thing can be a function and be imported at the same time).

data.title: Support curly braces for defining "chunk options" in fenced code blocks of markdown documents
data.body:
Rmarkdown (http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/) enables creation of reproducible documents using R. The main deviation of Rmarkdown from CommonMark is the use of curly braces in the header of fenced code blocks to define options related to the rendering of the figure/table described in the chunk. It would be nice if VS Code does proper syntax highlighting of code blocks in Rmarkdown documents. - VSCode Version: 1.1.3 Example code block: 
```{r include=FALSE, pdf.width=100px}
ggplot(foo, aes(x=bar, y=baz)) + geom_boxplot()
```
